Lagarde on the European Green Deal: We will play our part within the framework of our mandate. The stakes are high enough that we should consider key questions while pursuing our primary mission (6/6)

Lagarde on cryptocurrencies: We are looking into the feasibility and merits of a central bank digital currency that would ensure that people can continue to use central bank money even if the use of physical cash eventually declines. We want to play an active role (5/6)

Lagarde on low rates: Interest rates are instruments rather than objectives in themselves. In the medium to long term, low rates ensure the best possible economic environment and the preservation of purchasing power for all, whether savers or borrowers (4/6)

Lagarde on bringing the ECB closer to people: This is one of my priorities. We need to engage with our fellow citizens and enter into dialogue with them. We need to explain to them what the ECB does and that we are committed to doing its work effectively (3/6)

Lagarde on a new policy mix: It makes sense to use all the tools we have to increase growth. Monetary policy, fiscal policy and structural reforms are the three elements to this policy mix. Greater cooperation between authorities can multiply the effects of their decisions (2/6)

As a supervisor of banks in the euro area, the ECB works closely with the Single Resolution Board throughout the resolution process. In particular, it assesses whether a bank is failing or likely to fail. Read our explainer to learn more https://t.co/EPnM8KdOcb

The Single Resolution Board is turning five this month! The @EU_SRB seeks to ensure that failing euro area banks are wound up in an orderly way, with as little impact as possible on taxpayers and public finances in euro area countries. Find out more https://t.co/zAC9Rf8CyH

Welcome @Isabel_Schnabel and Fabio Panetta, who took up their positions as ECB Executive Board members on 1 January. We wish them all the best for their eight-year terms of office. https://t.co/ZGXz1gdyG2

Happy new year – all the best for 2020 from all of us at the ECB!

#happynewyear #2020 https://t.co/6v7sb9hnAa

Today is Benoît Cœuré’s last day as a member of the ECB’s Executive Board. We recently said farewell to Mr Cœuré, paying tribute to his work and wishing him all the best for the future. Mr Cœuré will start his new role as Head of the new @BIS_org Innovation Hub on 15 January. https://t.co/pbN7eOqqv0

Last but not least…we welcomed our new President Christine @Lagarde! Every new ECB president provides their signature for use on euro banknotes. Notes with President Lagarde’s signature will gradually enter into circulation in 2020.
We hope you enjoyed our look back at 2019! https://t.co/EOuaZeyPEt

In October we launched the €STR, a new benchmark interest rate. Benchmark rates play a key role in the economic system and reform is essential to ensure they remain reliable and unbiased. https://t.co/ShJ49h8owT

Speaking of diverse channels, September saw us join the world of podcasting. We’re giving our voices a rest right now after all the carol-singing in December but we'll see you in January for the next instalment! Catch up on the first three episodes here https://t.co/upILFNG0mO https://t.co/VJaOatWb08

We like to speak to you through a wide range of channels. This year our Chief Economist Philip R. Lane and his predecessor Peter Praet answered questions live on Twitter about central bank independence, bitcoin and how they prepare for Governing Council meetings. https://t.co/vkRuIJ9XPE

We had another anniversary this year: European banking supervision turned five! In an interview, Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria gave us his thoughts on what the next five years might hold. https://t.co/pGSvqFeepL
This year marked 20 years since the launch of the euro and support for our single currency also reached a record high! #EUROat20 https://t.co/cna3m9IQOw

⬆️ This was the short version – head to our website to read the full paper (at 335 pages, it’s perfect holiday reading!) https://t.co/7zIutUsIgD

The paper uses new methods to quantify the impact of these measures on GDP and inflation and capture the interactions between the instruments. It finds that they provided significant support to economic growth, job creation and inflation.

The monetary policy framework had to evolve. While the definition of price stability helped guide the response, a more diverse range of instruments was needed to keep inflation “close to 2%”. These included negative interest rates, forward guidance, asset purchases and TLTROs.

In the wake of the European debt crisis, however, the pressures on inflation reversed and the 2% ceiling was no longer as effective in acting as a shock-absorber. Negative shocks to inflation were accompanied by declining inflation expectations and lower core inflation.

The ECB’s definition of price stability – inflation below, but close to, 2% – served the institution well in its first decade. When inflation exceeded 2%, investors expected the ECB to react vigorously, which kept inflation expectations in check and inflation overshoots moderate.

The first 20 years of the ECB were characterised by two inflation regimes: the first was marked by shocks that largely pushed inflation up, and the second saw shocks that mainly pushed inflation down. The European debt crisis was the watershed dividing the two phases.

(THREAD) Today the ECB published “A tale of two decades: the ECB’s monetary policy at 20”, a working paper (reflecting the views of the authors) which looks at the first 20 years of the ECB’s monetary policy https://t.co/7zIutUsIgD
